content: Variables are containers for storing data values. In Python, variable names must follow these rules:
rules: Must start with a letter (a-z, A-Z) or underscore (_)
Can only contain letters, numbers, and underscores
Cannot contain spaces or special characters
Cannot be Python keywords (if, for, while, etc.)
Are case-sensitive (age and Age are different)

content: The print() function outputs text to the screen. It's one of the most basic and useful functions in Python.
rules: You can use single quotes ' or double quotes "
Multiple items can be separated by commas

content: Python has several built-in data types. Each type serves a different purpose in programming.
Syntax errors occur when Python can't understand your code. They must be fixed before your program can run.
rules: Always end if/for/while/def/class with a colon (:)
Match all parentheses (), brackets [], and braces {}
Match all quotes - start and end with the same type
Don't forget commas between list items

wrong: for i in range(5)    # Missing colon
correct: for i in range(5):   # Has colon

content: Python uses indentation to define code blocks. This is different from most other programming languages.
rules: Code inside a block must be indented
All lines in the same block need equal indentation
Indentation errors will crash your program

content: range() generates a sequence of numbers. It's essential for creating loops with specific counts.
rules: range(n) gives numbers from 0 to n-1
range(start, stop) gives start to stop-1
range(start, stop, step) adds a step value
The stop value is never included in the output
range() is memory efficient for large sequences

content: List comprehensions create lists in a single line. They are more concise than traditional for loops.
rules: Can include conditions: [expr for item in list if condition]

code: evens = [n for n in nums if n % 2 == 0]

content: Dictionaries store data as key-value pairs. They provide fast lookup by key.
rules: Each entry has a key and value: {key: value}
Use 'in' to check if a key exists
Keys must be unique and immutable

content: Sorting arranges list elements in order. Python offers flexible sorting options.
rules: sorted() returns a new sorted list
